title: Aglaope
html:
Aglaope

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search
n Aglaope (No tile)
Difficulty 20 (dNetHack)
22 (SlashTHEM)
Attacks Claw 4d4 quest-artifact-stealing, Claw 0d0 seduction, Singing (dNetHack)
Cast 0d0 mage spell, Claw 0d0 seduction, Cast 0d0 mage spell (SlashTHEM)
n Aglaope (No tile)
Difficulty 20 (dNetHack)
22 (SlashTHEM)
Attacks

Claw 4d4 quest-artifact-stealing, Claw 0d0 seduction, Singing (dNetHack)
Cast 0d0 mage spell, Claw 0d0 seduction, Cast 0d0 mage spell (SlashTHEM)

Base level 17
Base experience 532
Speed 9
Base AC -4
Base MR 90
Alignment -15 (chaotic)
Frequency (by normal means) 0 (Not randomly generated)
Genocidable No
Weight 600
Nutritional value 300
Size medium
Resistances sleep, petrification
Resistances conveyed none

Aglaope:

  • has a head, a couple of arms, and a torso.
  • can teleport.
  • has teleport control.
  • does not eat. (*)
  • is not a valid polymorphable form.
  • is a lord to its kind.
  • is female.
  • is normally generated hostile.
  • can pick up weapons and food.
  • can pick up magical items.
  • wants the Amulet of Yendor.
  • wants your quest artifact.
  • waits for you to come.
  • wants the Amulet of Yendor, the Bell of Opening, the Book of the Dead, the Candelabrum of Invocation, and your quest artifact.
  • has infravision.
  • can be seen through infravision.
  • cannot be tamed.

Aglaope, n, is the Bard quest nemesis in dNetHack and SlashTHEM. She is a nymph that guards the Bell of Opening and the Bard quest artifact, The Lyre of Orpheus. Her behavior and attack patterns depend on the variant - in both variants, Aglaope is capable of "countersinging" that decreases the effectiveness of any musicalize spells you cast around her.

Contents

  • 1 Generation
  • 2 dNetHack
  • 3 SlashTHEM
  • 4 Strategy
    • 4.1 dNetHack
  • 5 Origin

Generation

Aglaope is generated meditating in the center of the ruins on the Bard quest goal level, with The Lyre of Orpheus and a pair of water walking boots on her square.

dNetHack

Aglaope possesses a claw attack that can steal The Lyre or the Amulet of Yendor from you if you possess either item. She also has the nymph's standard seduction attack that lets her steal one or more items, possibly causing you to disrobe as well, before warping away. In dNetHack, Aglaope will sing one of the following songs before each of her attacks:

  • Encouragement: Increases damage from hostile monsters by 1+level/3, where level is Aglaope's current monster level.
  • Good health: Cures paralysis, blindness, laughing, berserk, stun, confusion, and scared statuses for all hostile monsters on the current level.
  • Haste: Increases the speed of hostile monsters on the current level by 12.
  • Dirge: Decreases damage from pets by -1-level/3, where level is Aglaope's current monster level.
  • Slowness: Decreases the speed of pets by 12.

All of these songs have a covetous-warping effect that brings you to her, rather than the other way around: this also cancels the effects of your current song, and ignores teleport control and no-teleport conditions.

SlashTHEM

In SlashTHEM, Aglaope instead has two spell-casting attacks, with her seduction theft attack in-between them.

Strategy

A player with stealth and a wand of death may be able to kill Aglaope before she can pick up The Lyre of Orpheus.

dNetHack

Defeating Aglaope in a straight fight can be surprisingly difficult even by the standard. A magic whistle is recommended to keep pets nearby after she forcibly warps you, and a worn engagement ring will block any nymph-style seduction attacks. A horde of high-level pets such as dragons, ancient nagas or master mind flayers can make extremely short work of her if whistled to her position.

Origin

Wikipedia has an article about:
Siren (mythology)

In Greek mythology, Aglaope (Ancient Greek: Ἀγλαόπη, "with lambent voice"), also called Aglaopheme (Ἀγλαοφήμη) and Aglaophonos (Ἀγλαόφωνος), is one of the Sirens, a group of humanlike beings with alluring voices. There are a varying number of Sirens named, ranging from two to as many as eight or even ten; they are generally attested as daughters of the river-god Achelous.

The Sirens first appear in a scene in Homer's Odyssey, where Odysseus orders his men to leave him tied to his ship's mast so that he can hear their hypnotic song; all of his sailors plugged their ears with beeswax as well. When he heard the Sirens' beautiful song, he ordered the sailors to untie him, but they bound him tighter until they had passed out of earshot. The Sirens are often described as beautiful women with bird-like or mermaid-like features, with Aglaope in dNetHack patterned after the former type (though the Sirens of the Odyssey are not described in the text).

She is a [[Nymph (monster class)|nymph]] that guards the [[Bell of Opening]] and the Bard [[quest artifact]], [[The Lyre of Orpheus]]. Her behavior and attack patterns depend on the variant - in both variants, Aglaope is capable of "[[countersinging]]" that decreases the effectiveness of any [[musicalize spell]]s you cast around her. ==Generation== Aglaope is generated [[meditating]] in the center of the ruins on the [[Bard quest]] goal level, with The Lyre of Orpheus and a pair of [[water walking boots]] on her square. ==dNetHack== Aglaope possesses a claw attack that can steal The Lyre or the [[Amulet of Yendor]] from [[you]] if you possess either item. She also has the nymph's standard seduction attack that lets her steal one or more items, possibly causing you to disrobe as well, before warping away. In dNetHack, Aglaope will sing one of the following songs before each of her attacks: * Encouragement: Increases damage from hostile monsters by 1+level/3, where level is Aglaope's current monster level. * Good health: Cures [[paralysis]], [[blindness]], [[laughing]], [[Berserk (dNetHack)|berserk]], [[stun]], [[confusion]], and [[scare]]d statuses for all hostile monsters on the current level. * Haste: Increases the speed of hostile monsters on the current level by 12. * Dirge: Decreases damage from pets by -1-level/3, where level is Aglaope's current monster level. * Slowness: Decreases the speed of pets by 12. All of these songs have a [[covetous]]-warping effect that brings ''you'' to her, rather than the other way around: this also cancels the effects of your current song, and ignores [[teleport control]] and [[no-teleport]] conditions. ==SlashTHEM== In SlashTHEM, Aglaope instead has two spell-casting attacks, with her seduction theft attack in-between them. ==Strategy== A player with [[stealth]] and a [[wand of death]] may be able to kill Aglaope before she can pick up The Lyre of Orpheus. ===dNetHack=== Defeating Aglaope in a straight fight can be surprisingly difficult even by the standard. A [[magic whistle]] is recommended to keep pets nearby after she forcibly warps you, and a worn [[engagement ring]] will block any nymph-style seduction attacks. A horde of high-level pets such as [[dragon]]s, [[ancient naga]]s or [[master mind flayer]]s can make extremely short work of her if whistled to her position. ==Origin== {{wikipedia|Siren (mythology)}} In Greek mythology, [[wikipedia:Aglaope (mythology)|Aglaope]] (Ancient Greek: Ἀγλαόπη, "with lambent voice"), also called Aglaopheme (Ἀγλαοφήμη) and Aglaophonos (Ἀγλαόφωνος), is one of the Sirens, a group of humanlike beings with alluring voices. There are a varying number of Sirens named, ranging from two to as many as eight or even ten; they are generally attested as daughters of the river-god Achelous. The Sirens first appear in a scene in [[wikipedia:Homer|Homer's]] ''[[wikipedia:Odyssey|Odyssey]]'', where Odysseus orders his men to leave him tied to his ship's mast so that he can hear their hypnotic song; all of his sailors plugged their ears with beeswax as well. When he heard the Sirens' beautiful song, he ordered the sailors to untie him, but they bound him tighter until they had passed out of earshot. The Sirens are often described as beautiful women with bird-like or mermaid-like features, with Aglaope in dNetHack patterned after the former type (though the Sirens of the ''Odyssey'' are not described in the text). {{variant-343}} [[Category:Bard patch]]
